ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot about how environmental policies and enforcement frameworks are created. There was a lot about environmental health in addition to food
Discussed environmental laws pertaining to a variety of topics including pesticides, plastics, food production, etc.
I gained a basic comprehensive knowledge of some of the biggest challenges in environmental law.
You learn a lot of broad and interesting knowledge about food and environmental policy around the world!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: Manageable workload, interesting topics
Weaknesses: Classes did not seem well planned out, assignments always required clarification
This course would probably be best taught as a lecture. But Professor Wargo was very knowledgeable and kind.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)

Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not really. The content had the potential to be super interesting, but I thought the class sessions were boring and unfocused. Prof Wargo is a crazy knowledgeable and very kind teacher, but not the best seminar leader. He's great one-on-one, though, and he was very willing to help out with the big final paper. Having a course dedicated around a final paper felt high-stakes because you don't really get any feedback on your work in the course until the end unless you go to office hours, but it was a rewarding experience to learn how to write a proper research paper.
Yes, low workload, interesting class. Do not take if the topics do not interest you.

This course is a very good overview of some of the biggest problems our environmental and agricultural systems are facing right now. However, a student can easily get by without doing much of the reading so the student gets out of it what they put in.
Yes! Especially if you are interested in environmental laws and food regulations.
